comments.commentBody: Most emphatically both on a scale that no one on earth truly has the words to describe.

comments.commentBody: The little North Korean despot should concern any rational adult of any nation. The fact that we have President Trump prime among Americans and our allies dealing with the little thug is a woe inside a woe.
As easily as these Norks played Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton, and the mendacious Barack Obama, you have no credibility talking about your President now.
comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene

comments.commentBody: I've been thinking about the tickling question for days. This Wikipedia entry has some info about how it is actually premeditated torture (quite a history there) and has at times been fatal. I can't imagine how ANYONE would enjoy being tickled to the point of gasping for breath. It actually hurts, a lot. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tickle_torture
Tickling can be torture.

Agreed, thank you!

I would have liked the Ethicist to consider whether the driver's being black and a woman led to assumptions on LW1's part about the funky smell and the driving quality. The unconscious is a very, very powerful thing.

The Ethicist should have asked LW1 to perform a thorough gut-check and ask: if the Uber driver were a middle-aged white man, would they really have smelled marijuana and/or thought the driving was unsafe?

WMK...it would appear that when you get involved in a cause in which you truly believe, no sequential logic, no context, no big picture, no perspective, no sex education, no modern contraceptive methods and no affordable healthcare stops you from going into your 'pro-life' dimension.

Congratulations on achieving your tunnel vision.

I wish the Ethicist had put it bluntly, without hesitation or digressive discourse. What the father is doing with the nine-year-old is child abuse. The father’s so-called justifications hold no water. If the child’s mother does not take steps to put an end to what is going on, as ethics requires her to, she is an enabler of the abuse.

The question is where the mother should turn for help if the father persists. The child’s pediatrician might be a good place to start.

The mother’s question to the Ethicist goes only to the tickling and wrestling. Without knowing, I fear that there are or will be other instances similar to the episodes recounted in the question. All the more reason to confront now what could be the father’s child abuse that goes beyond the question.

I am not suggesting the “other instances” involve sexual abuse. I am speaking to the child abuse shown by the question.

I wrote this before I read any of the Comments. Nice to see that I am in good company in my assessment and nice to see that so many of the Comments want to set the Ethicist straight.

Is it possible for one sibling to instigate something and then use the inevitable retaliation as an excuse to go running to the parent?  Of course.  But this situation does not involve siblings, or two kids.  We expect different, and better, behavior from adults because they're, you know, adults.  There is something very off here, and the mom needs to be a parent and protect her kid, even if the one she needs protection from is the dad.  Maybe especially if it's the dad.

I don't think it's a foregone conclusion  that "states must control their borders".  It's certainly  an assumption that is worth questioning from both ethical and economic perspectives. Many economists will tell you that restrictions on migration cause the global economy to suffer greatly, with vast amounts of  human potential languishing behind borders. And ethically, one should ask whether borders cause a net decrease in human suffering, compared to a borderless world. There isn't anything natural or inevitable about limiting access to a planet we all inhabit.
No, I (for one) and transplant patients survive because of them. However, as medicines they require detailed and careful management.
Totally. She is well now, though her recovery was difficult.
I agree! I really miss the Think Like A Doctor column. Is it gone for good?
Very easy to criticize when it is not your bones being permanently damaged. I was bedridden, now I am not. You don't make the call for anyone else.

Biologic response inhibitors are not a pill that the doctor prescribes and then forgets about you. Mine is a 3-hour drip infusion in a clinical setting, and my vital signs are constantly monitored the whole time. I have to see the rheumatologist in between every infusion. I don't know what that woman's doctor was thinking, but an open sore mean the imfusions have to stop til it heals. So don't judge the rest of us based on this story. Also most people who get psoriasis don't have bone onvolvement, so count yourself lucky instead of judging someone else's pain.

I'm not a doctor, but I do have an extensive experience from taking immune suppressants for years. This kind of fungus can be inhaled since it is found in soil. One disturbs soil while, for instance, gardening and one can inhale the fungus. HOWEVER, this fungus (and associated histoplasmosis)  rarely affects people with a normal immune system. This lady was taking immune suppressants which certainly lowered her tolerance, and ability, to deal with it. I've been warned against a number of these seemingly inocuous things to avoid infections.

I read Un Roman russe when it first came out in 2007, as it had attracted a lot of critical attention. I found it to be totally undisciplined and obnoxiously self-indulgent. Has he really gotten better since then?

I so often feel that people who are depressed are missing something, which is to immerse themselves in the development of a child, or of children.  So often great artists fall into depression-- the vacuum which appears when they are not working.  And yet so many, like Carrere, never speak of children and what profound meaning their developing lives offer to those of us who are stuck in the long, static years of adulthood.
To be depressed is a medical condition. It is not missing on reaching out, it is being assaulted from within and it hurts whether you reach out or not.
IF they are lucky enough to have a typical child.  Believe me I know what I'm talking about - it's not a silver bullet.

Carrère does not speak of his three children in this interview/article, true. But he writes about them extensively in his books. Are you upset that the interviewer didn't seem to ask him questions about his children, or are you judging Carrère for being depressed despite his love of/interest in his children? Very strange complaint!
The author of the article has translated five books by Michon, and has written about de Kerangal.

I agree also - in fact I just finished Roman Russe (my Life as a Russian Novel), having read several other of his works over the years in the original French. A very compelling first person voice - reflective, sometimes quite funny -  and yes flawed - in essence very human.
Some people just aren't very organised.
You should hold a bark mitzvah.  Hopefully that will secure the dog's fate

It's my dog. My husband abbreviated things. Riley the wiener dog gets Rileytoberfest in October which is an LSU football party and Loupe the Chihuahua gets a Cinco de Loupe in May. I found her on the road in one May. She was pregnant and I delivered puppies and found them homes.
My husband and I eloped to Vegas a few years back and I guess I wanted the dog wedding to have a party for everyone who couldn't make the flight.
It wasn't a white privilege thing.
I am a critical care nurse and get down sometimes and the best way to fix things is a party. The wedding would have been pat Mardi Gras but pre- summer.
How on earth do you know?

Buses, too--years ago my family was in Rome and a crowd of young Gypsy children surrounded my mom, and after they flew out the door at a stop, we realized they'd stolen her wallet. It was common then for the children to prey on tourists. At the time we were so upset and angry and it still bothers me--they thought we were rich Americans, and we certainly were not. I realize now, though, that even though we were not rich by American standards, compared to them we had so much, and they probably had so little.

Sorry, I just noticed that soy sauce is in that recipe for Worcestershire Sauce. I cannot use that either because it is high in free glutamate. So, I think I'll just omit it and make the whole thing this way.

I am indeed extremely angry at Democrats who are so actively setting themselves up to do the same thing again. We should at least be bottoming out with Trump.

They deny and excuse their own error, and blame everything but what they did.

Most of all, they blame voters for how they voted, instead of blaming the party and candidate for not winning those votes. They got to the extreme of insulting those voters, an absolutely sure route to losing again. And they are sanctimonious while doing that.
